dos Santos Patrício''' {{small|[[Order of Merit (Portugal)|ComM]]}} ({{IPA-pt|ˈʁuj pɐˈtɾisju}}; born 15 February 1988) is a Portuguese professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]] for English club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] and the [[Portugal national football team|Portugal national team]].
Before moving to England, he spent most of his career with [[Sporting CP]], making his debut with the first team at only 18 and going on to appear in 467 official games. He won five trophies during his 12-year spell there, including two [[Taça de Portugal|Portuguese Cups]].
Patrício earned his first [[Cap (sport)|cap]] for Portugal in 2010, after [[Paulo Bento]]'s appointment as head coach. He represented the nation in two [[FIFA World Cup|World Cups]] and three [[UEFA European Championship|European Championships]], winning the [[UEFA Euro 2016|2016 edition]] of the latter tournament.
==Club career== ===Sporting=== Born in Marrazes, [[Leiria]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maisfutebol.iol.pt/liga/sporting/patricio-inaugura-estatua-em-leiria-que-seja-exemplo-para-mais-novos|title=Patrício inaugura estátua em Leiria: "Que seja exemplo para mais novos"|trans-title=Patrício inaugurates statue in Leiria: «Let it be an example for the young ones»|publisher=Mais Futebol|language=pt|date=22 May 2017|accessdate=30 August 2018}}</ref> Patrício played as a [[Forward (association football)#Striker|striker]] at a young age. Reportedly, a [[Sporting CP]] scout was in the area and saw him play [[Goalkeeper (association football)|in goal]], being impressed enough to sign the 12-year-old to the club's youth academy.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.cmjornal.pt/desporto/detalhe/heroi-ja-foi-avancado|title=Herói já foi avançado|trans-title=Hero used to be a forward|newspaper=[[Correio da Manhã]]|language=pt|date=6 August 2009|accessdate=7 April 2018}}</ref> He made his [[Primeira Liga]] debut on 19 November 2006, in a 1–0 away win against [[C.S. Marítimo]] in the tenth round: standing in for habitual club and [[Portugal national football team|country]] first-choice [[Ricardo (footballer, born 1976)|Ricardo]], he saved a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty kick]] 15 minutes before the end of the game.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/arquivo/interior.aspx?content_id=289099|title=Rui Patrício entra na história|trans-title=Rui Patrício makes history|newspaper=[[Record (newspaper)|Record]]|language=pt|date=20 November 2006|accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref> [[File:Rui Patrício.jpg|left|thumb|271x271px|Patrício with Sporting in 2012]] In the [[2007–08 Primeira Liga|2007–08 season]], after Ricardo's departure to [[Real Betis]], Patrício beat competition from Sporting veteran [[Tiago Ferreira (footballer, born 1975)|Tiago]] and new signing [[Vladimir Stojković]] to become the undisputed starter. He made his [[UEFA Champions League]] debut on 27 November 2007, in a [[2007–08 UEFA Champions League|1–2 group stage loss]] at [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2008/matches/round=15105/match=301234/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Ronaldo underlines United authority|publisher=UEFA|date=27 November 2007|accessdate=15 March 2016}}</ref>
During the 2008 off-season, Patrício was the subject of a rumored transfer to Italian giants [[Inter Milan]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=791670&idCanal=24|title=Rui Patrício por Toldo|trans-title=Rui Patrício for Toldo|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=17 June 2008|accessdate=|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080809164349/http://www.record.pt/noticia.asp?id=791670&idCanal=24|archivedate=9 August 2008}}</ref> Nothing came of it, however, and in [[2008 Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira|that year]]'s [[Supertaça Cândido de Oliveira|Portuguese Supercup]] final, against [[FC Porto]], he stopped a [[Lucho González]] penalty in a 2–0 final success,<ref name=SUPERCUP>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/memberassociations/news/newsid=739742.html|title=Djaló double steers Sporting success|publisher=UEFA|date=16 August 2008|accessdate=22 October 2013}}</ref> also being an everpresent fixture in [[2008–09 Primeira Liga|the league]].
In the qualifying rounds of the [[2009–10 UEFA Champions League|2009–10 Champions League]], at [[FC Twente]], Sporting were trailing 0–1 in the 94th minute, after a 0–0 tie in the first leg: Patrício rushed to the opposing area for a [[corner kick]], where he went up for a header with [[Nikita Rukavytsya]]. Both players seemed to make contact with the ball, and it was helped into the net for an [[own goal]] via the boot of [[Peter Wisgerhof]] as the latter side eventually qualified for the last games prior to the group stage.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/matches/season=2010/round=2000026/match=2000341/index.html|title=Sporting late show shatters Twente|publisher=UEFA|date=4 August 2009|accessdate=5 August 2009}}</ref>
On 20 December 2012, Patrício was awarded Sporting's Footballer of the Year award for a second consecutive year.<ref name="POY12">{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/Sporting//interior.aspx?content_id=795037|title=Vencedores dos prémios Stromp|trans-title=Stromp awards winners|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=20 December 2012|accessdate=23 December 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121226102314/http://www.record.xl.pt/Futebol/Nacional/1a_liga/Sporting/interior.aspx?content_id=795037|archivedate=26 December 2012}}</ref> On 18 October 2014, with the score at 2–1 for his team, he saved a penalty by [[Jackson Martínez]] to help [[2014–15 Taça de Portugal|oust Porto]] from the [[Taça de Portugal|Portuguese Cup]] with a 3–1 win at the ''[[Estádio do Dragão]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.portugoal.net/club-news/77-sporting-dump-porto-out-of-the-portuguese-cup|title=Sporting dump Porto out of the Portuguese Cup|publisher=PortuGOAL|date=18 October 2014|accessdate=21 October 2014}}</ref>
On 24 October 2016, Patrício was one of 30 players nominated for the 2016 [[Ballon d'Or]] award alongside [[Portugal national football team|Portugal]] teammates [[Pepe (footballer, born 1983)|Pepe]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.com/uefa-champions-league/story/2980138/ballon-dor-nominees-cristiano-ronaldo-and-lionel-messi-lead-list-of-30|title=Ballon d'Or: Cristiano Ronaldo and Lionel Messi lead list of 30 nominees|publisher=[[ESPN FC]]|last=Holyman|first=Ian|date=24 October 2016|accessdate=3 November 2016}}</ref> The following 18 February he appeared in his 400th competitive game with Sporting, putting on a [[Man of the match]] performance in a 1–0 home win against [[Rio Ave F.C.|Rio Ave FC]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sporting.pt/en/news/football/main-team/2017-02-19/sporting-cp-1-rio-ave-0|title=Patrício secures 400th {{sic|nolink=y|apperance}} with fantastic performance|publisher=Sporting CP|date=18 February 2017|accessdate=19 February 2017}}</ref>
On 15 May 2018, Patrício and several of his teammates, including coaches, were injured following an attack by around 50 supporters of Sporting at the club's training ground after the team [[2017–18 Primeira Liga|finished third in the league]] and missed out on [[2018–19 UEFA Champions League|Champions League qualification]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.abola.pt/Nnh/Noticias/Ver/730529|title=Jesus e jogadores agredidos na Academia|trans-title=Jesus and players attacked at the Academy|newspaper=[[A Bola]]|language=pt|date=15 May 2018|access-date=16 May 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sportsjoe.ie/football/sporting-lisbon-attack-160186|title=Sporting Lisbon players attacked at training ground after failing to secure Champions League spot|publisher=Sports Joe|last=Kiley|first=Ben|date=15 May 2018|access-date=16 May 2018}}</ref> Despite the events, he and the rest of the team agreed to play in the [[2018 Taça de Portugal Final|Portuguese Cup final]] scheduled for the following weekend,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/amp/football/44142885|title=Sporting Lisbon: Players agree to play Portuguese Cup final after attack|publisher=[[BBC Sport]]|date=16 May 2018|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> eventually losing to [[C.D. Aves]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.ojogo.pt/futebol/taca-portugal/noticias/interior/aves-ganha-a-taca-de-portugal-gracas-a-bis-de-guedes-9360212.html|title=Aves ganha a Taça de Portugal graças a bis de Guedes|trans-title=Aves win Portuguese Cup thanks to Guedes brace|newspaper=[[O Jogo]]|language=pt|date=20 May 2018|accessdate=26 July 2018}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 1 June 2018, Patrício submitted a request to terminate his Sporting contract with grounds for just cause, due to the dressing room violence from supporters as well as seeing an €18 million move to newly promoted [[Premier League]] team [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] fall through, after Sporting president [[Bruno de Carvalho]] pulled out of negotiations at the last minute.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.abola.pt/img/carta-rui-patricio-A.pdf|title=Rescisão com justa causa do contrato de trabalho desportivo|trans-title=Just cause termination of sporting work contract|newspaper=A Bola|language=pt|date=31 May 2018|access-date=3 June 2018}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://kwese.espn.com/football/soccer-transfers/story/3515658/rui-patricio-wants-sporting-deal-terminated-as-jorge-mendes-accused-of-blackmail|title=Rui Patricio wants Sporting deal terminated as Jorge Mendes accused of 'blackmail'|publisher=[[ESPN]]|date=2 June 2018|accessdate=3 June 2018}}</ref> He completed the move on 18 June, on a four-year deal,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180618-wolves-complete-patricio-signing/|title=Wolves complete Patricio signing|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C|date=18 June 2018|accessdate=18 June 2018}}</ref> and it was announced on 31 October that both clubs had agreed a €18 million deal as settlement of his departure to England.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/46052450|title=Rui Patricio: Wolves agree £16m fee with Sporting Lisbon for goalkeeper|publisher=BBC Sport|date=31 October 2018|accessdate=4 November 2018}}</ref>
Patrício opted to wear the No.11 shirt for Wolves as opposed to the habitual No.1, in honour of [[Carl Ikeme]], who had just retired following treatment for [[Acute leukemia|acute leukaemia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2018/08/10/rui-patricio-honours-carl-ikeme-as-wolves-reveal-new-kit-numbers/|title=Rui Patricio honours Carl Ikeme as Wolves reveal new kit numbers|newspaper=[[Express & Star]]|last=Hatfield|first=Luke|date=10 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref> He made his league debut on 11 August 2018, in a 2–2 home draw against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/45067374|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 2–2 Everton|publisher=BBC Sport|last=Hafez|first=Shamoon|date=11 August 2018|accessdate=14 August 2018}}</ref>
==International career== [[File:Rui Patrício 2017.jpg|left|thumb|285x285px|Patrício with Portugal at the [[2017 FIFA Confederations Cup|2017 Confederations Cup]]]] From 2007, Patrício started appearing for the [[Portugal national under-21 football team|Portuguese under-21 side]]. On 29 January of the following year, [[Portugal national football team|senior team]] coach [[Luiz Felipe Scolari]] called him up for a 1–3 [[Exhibition game|friendly]] defeat against [[Italy national football team|Italy]] in [[Zürich]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.record.xl.pt/arquivo/interior.aspx?content_id=331094|title=Rui Patrício chamado por Scolari|trans-title=Rui Patrício called by Scolari|newspaper=Record|language=pt|date=29 January 2008|accessdate=15 February 2013}}</ref> although he did not leave the bench; on 12 May he was picked to the squad for [[UEFA Euro 2008]], but did not play in the tournament.
Although not part of the provisional 24-player list for the [[2010 FIFA World Cup]] in South Africa,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=9126513|title=Convocados revelados|trans-title=Squad revealed|publisher=[[Portuguese Football Federation]]|language=pt|date=10 May 2010|accessdate=11 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110615170243/http://www.fpf.pt/portal/page/portal/PORTAL_FUTEBOL/SELECCOES/NOTICIA?notid=9126513|archivedate=15 June 2011|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/newsid=1208424/index.html|title=Pepe in Portugal squad|publisher=FIFA|date=10 May 2010|accessdate=11 May 2010}}</ref> Patrício was named in a backup list of six players.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/mm/document/tournament/competition/01/20/86/87/provisional1305.pdf|title=Release list of up to 30 players|publisher=FIFA|accessdate=14 May 2010}}</ref> He made his debut on 17 November 2010, playing the second half of a 4–0 friendly win with [[Spain national football team|Spain]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnstar.com/football/news/detail/item533498/Portugal-4-0-Spain/|title=Portugal 4–0 Spain|publisher=[[ESPN Star Sports]]|date=18 November 2010|accessdate=11 February 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120731010828/http://www.espnstar.com/football/news/detail/item533498/Portugal-4-0-Spain/|archivedate=31 July 2012}}</ref>
After [[Eduardo Carvalho|Eduardo]] was relegated to the bench at his new club, [[S.L. Benfica]], Patrício became the starter under national team boss [[Paulo Bento]], and both players finished the [[UEFA Euro 2012 qualifying|Euro 2012 qualifying campaign]] with five games (450 minutes) as Portugal qualified for the final stages. He was the starter in the finals in [[Poland]] and [[Ukraine]], conceding four goals in five matches in an eventual semi-final exit.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2012/matches/round=15174/match=2003378/postmatch/report/index.html#spain+survive+test+nerve+reach+final|title=Spain survive test of nerve to reach final|publisher=UEFA|date=27 June 2012|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
Patrício was included in Bento's 23-man squad for the [[2014 FIFA World Cup|2014 World Cup]] as first-choice,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/teams/portugal/10810443/Portugal-World-Cup-2014-squad.html|title=Portugal World Cup 2014 squad|newspaper=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=2 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> and made his debut in [[FIFA World Cup|the competition]] in the first encounter against [[Germany national football team|Germany]], which ended with a 0–4 loss.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/worldcup/news/y=2014/m=6/news=german-lessons-for-cr7-s-portugal-2373410.html|title=Muller-inspired Germany thrash ten-man Portugal|publisher=FIFA|date=16 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref> He missed the second game against the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States]], due to injury.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/worldcup2014/article-2660580/Portugal-defender-Fabio-Coentrao-ruled-rest-World-Cup-thigh-injury.html|title=Portugal defender Fabio Coentrao ruled out for rest of the World Cup with thigh injury|newspaper=[[Daily Mail]]|date=17 June 2014|accessdate=26 June 2014}}</ref>
Patrício appeared in his 50th international on 30 June 2016, during [[UEFA Euro 2016|Euro 2016]]: after the 1–1 draw to [[Poland national football team|Poland]] at the ''[[Stade Vélodrome]]'' during the first 120 minutes, he saved [[Jakub Błaszczykowski]]'s attempt in a 5–3 [[Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalty shootout]] win that qualified to the semi-finals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefaeuro/season=2016/matches/round=2000449/match=2017901/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Draw specialists Portugal beat Poland on penalties|publisher=UEFA|date=30 June 2016|accessdate=30 June 2016}}</ref> Having won the tournament with a solid display in [[UEFA Euro 2016 Final|the final]],<ref name=BBC>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/36696772|title=Portugal 1–0 France|publisher=BBC Sport|last=McNulty|first=Phil|date=10 July 2016|accessdate=18 May 2018}}</ref> he also made the squad for the [[2018 FIFA World Cup|2018 World Cup]] in [[Russia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sbs.com.au/news/portugal-world-cup-squad|title=Nearly half Portugal's Euro squad to miss World Cup|publisher=[[Special Broadcasting Service]]|date=17 May 2018|accessdate=17 May 2018}}</ref>
